vocabInfos.lsjDefs:
βάρβᾰρος, ον,
barbarous, i.e. non-Greek, foreign, not in [Refs 8th c.BC+]; especially as substantive βάρβαροι, οἱ, originally all non-Greek-speaking peoples, then specially of the Medes and Persians, [Refs 5th c.BC+]; β. πόλεμον war with the barbarians, [Refs 5th c.BC+]; ἡ βάρβαρος (i.e. γῆ), opposed to αἱ Ἑλληνίδες πόλεις, [Refs 5th c.BC+] adverb -ρως, opposed to Ἑλληνικῶς,[Refs 3rd c.AD+]
__2 especially of language, φωνὴ β. [Refs 5th c.BC+]; συλλραφαί[Refs 4th c.BC+]; of birds, [Refs 5th c.BC+] adverb, βαρβάρως, ὠνόμασται have foreign names, [Refs 1st c.BC+]
__3 Grammars, of bad Greek, [Refs 2nd c.AD+]; τὸ β., of style, opposed to Ἑλληνικόν, [Refs 2nd c.AD+]
__II after the Persian war, brutal, rude, ἀμαθὴς καὶ β. [Refs 5th c.BC+]: comparative -ώτερος[Refs 5th c.BC+] Eph.2.4: superlative, πάντων βαρβαρώτατος θεῶν [Refs 5th c.BC+]
__III used by Jews of Greeks, [LXX]
__IV name for various plasters, [Refs 1st c.BC+]
vocabInfos.shortDef: non-Greek, foreign, "barbarian"; someone who speaks an unintelligible language
vocabInfos.mediumDef:
non-Greek, foreign, "barbarian"; someone who speaks an unintelligible language
primarily one to whom a pure Greek dialect is not native; one who is not a proper Greek, a barbarian, Rom. 1:14; Col. 3:11; Acts 28:2, 4; a foreigner speaking a strange or unintelligible language, 1Cor. 14:11*
vocabInfos._es_Definition: el que no es griego ; incivilizado ; extranjero ; nativo (HCH.28:2,4)
